Problem:
Consider the heat equation \\( u_t = k \\Delta u \\) in a domain \\( D \\) with boundary conditions prescribed on \\( \\partial D \\). An input function \\( h(x,t) \\) represents the external heat added per unit time. We consider the impact of the integral transformation \\( T[u](x,t) = u(x,t) + \\int_0^t h(x, \\tau) \\, d\\tau \\) on the system over time t.

If at a specific time \\( t_1 \\), an additional heat source \\( j(x,t) \\) starts influencing the system through the transformation \\( G[u](x,t) = u(x,t) + \\int_{t_1}^t j(x, \\tau) \\, d\\tau \\), will the final temperature distribution \\( u(x,T) \\) for T > t_1 be independent of the heat input \\( h(x,t) \\) and depend solely on \\( j(x,t) \\)?
Explanation: Both \\( h(x,t) \\) and \\( j(x,t) \\) contribute to the overall heat input, affecting the temperature distribution over time. The final state \\( u(x,T) \\) is influenced by the cumulative effect of both heat sources; therefore, it depends on both, not just \\( j(x,t) \\).
